IGF::OT::IGF THE GLOBAL PRECIPITATION MEASUREMENT (GPM) MISSION WILL RELY ON A CONSTELLATION OF COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND OPERATIONAL SATELLITES ON MULTIPLE LOW EARTH ORBITING (POLAR AND LOW INCLINATION ORBITS) TO OFFER FREQUENT TEMPORAL SAMPLING FOR GLOBAL PRECIPITATION ESTIMATES. AS WE APPROACH THE TARGETED LAUNCH DATE IN EARLY 2014 OF THE GPM CORE OBSERVATORY , WHICH WILL CARRY AN ADVANCED RADIOMETER/RADAR SYSTEM THAT IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE UNIFICATION OF THE SUITE OF MICROWAVE SENSORS ABOARD THE GPM CONSTELLATION, MEMBER AGENCIES OF THE JOINT CENTER OF SATELLITE DATA ASSIMILATION (JCSDA) ARE PREPARING TO ASSIMILATE PRECIPITATION AFFECTED MEASUREMENTS FROM GPM INSTRUMENTS INTO NUMERICAL WEATHER PREDICTION (NWP) MODELS TO IMPROVE CLOUD/PRECIPITATION FORECASTING CAPABILITIES. IN RESPONSE TO THIS SOLICITATION, THE CONTRACTOR WILL 1) EVALUATE AND REFINE AN OBSERVATION OPERATOR BASED ON THE JCSDA COMMUNITY RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL (CRTM) FOR USE IN THE ASSIMILATION OF PRECIPITATION-AFFECTED RADIANCES (AND PRECIPITATION PRODUCTS) FROM THE GPM SENSORS, USING REAL DATA FROM CURRENT ORBITING IMAGING AND SOUNDING INSTRUMENTS (E.G., TMI, AMSU) AND 2) PERFORM A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF THE QUALITY OF THE NWP FORECAST FIELDS USED AS BACKGROUND IN THE ASSIMILATION PROCESS. THE RESULTS OF THIS ANALYSIS ARE IMPORTANT IN PARTICULAR FOR THE QUALITY CONTROL OF THE INCOMING OBSERVATIONS AND FOR ASSESSING FORECASTS BACKGROUND AND FORWARD MODEL ERROR STATISTICS. IN THIS ANALYSIS DETAILED PROFILE INFORMATION FROM RADAR MEASUREMENTS WILL BE USED AS OUR MAIN REFERENCE. VALIDATION WILL BE DONE IN A 1DVAR OPTIMAL ESTIMATION FRAMEWORK RELYING ON APPROACHES PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED BY THE TRMM SCIENCE TEAM TO ALLOW US TO ADJUST MISSING (OR UNCERTAIN) GEOPHYSICAL VARIABLE ESTIMATES WITHIN CONSTRAINTS DERIVED FROM CLIMATOLOGY AND LOCAL ENSEMBLE RUNS FROM REGIONAL MODELS. IN PARTICULAR, WE WILL TEST DIFFERENT OPTICAL PROPERTY TABLES USED IN RADIATIVE TRANSFER CALCULATIONS TO TRANSLATE PRECIPITATION PROFILES PRODUCED BY THE FORECAST MODEL INTO RADIANCES AND ASSESS THE IMPACT OF ASSUMED OPTICAL PROPERTIES ON THE SKILLS OF THE OBSERVATION OPERATOR. IN FUTURE OPERATIONS, IT IS ALSO CRITICAL TO ENSURE THAT THE VARIOUS SENSORS IN THE CONSTELLATION PROVIDE CONSISTENT INFORMATION. BIAS CORRECTION SCHEMES EMPLOYED IN ASSIMILATION ARE DESIGNED TO EFFECTIVELY CALIBRATE THE SENSORS USING A COMMON REFERENCE (I.E., THE FORECAST MODEL FIELDS). IN THE CLEAR-SKY, WE TRADITIONALLY OPERATE UNDER THE ASSUMPTION OF HORIZONTAL HOMOGENEITY (PLANE PARALLEL ASSUMPTION) AND IT IS ASSUMED THAT DEPENDENCE OF RADIANCES ON VIEWING ANGLE IS ENTIRELY EXPLAINED BY VARIATIONS IN ATMOSPHERIC PATH. THE AVAILABILITY OF COINCIDENT INFORMATION FROM SENSORS ON DIFFERENT ORBITS WILL ALLOW US TO ASSESS HOW FINE-SCALES CLOUD STRUCTURE IMPACTS MEASUREMENTS MADE UNDER DIFFERENT VIEWING CONDITIONS. FOR THIS EFFORT, THE TARGET IS THE NAVY S GLOBAL NAVGEM MODEL BUT MANY ASPECTS OF THIS WORK ARE GENERIC AND APPLY TO OTHER NWP MODELS AS WELL. RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL ALSO BE REFLECTED IN FUTURE VERSIONS OF THE CRTM AND THUS WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER USER-COMMUNITY. THE PROPOSED PREPARATORY WORK IS PARTICULARLY RESPONSIVE TO THE INTERESTS OF THE JCSDA AND NRL IN PARTICULAR IN ASSIMILATING CLOUDY DATA FROM FUTURE GPM SATELLITE CONSTELLATION AND, AS SUCH, DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE JCSDA S GOAL TO ACCELERATE THE ABILITIES OF NOAA, DOD AND NASA TO INGEST DATA FROM CURRENT AND PLANNED SATELLITE MISSION AS WELL AS NASA BROADER LONG-TERM OBJECTIVES UNDER NASA NRA A.33 (DATA FOR OPERATION AND ASSESSMENT) TO USE GLOBAL MEASUREMENTS TO UNDERSTAND THE EARTH SYSTEMS AND ITS INTERACTIONS AS STEPS TOWARD ULTIMATELY ENABLING PREDICTION OF EARTH BEHAVIOR .
MODIFICATION TO UPDATE DIRECT DELIVERY ADDRESS FOR THREE (3) HOUSING BEARING UNITS. REMAINING 32 UNITS WILL BE SHIPPED TO SFLC WAREHOUSE.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF MOD TO CORRECT WAWF CLAUSE
IGF::CT,CL::IGF INCREMENTAL FUNDING FOR CONTRACTOR SUPPORT

STAR FORMATION TYPICALLY BEGINS IN COLD, DARK CLOUDS THAT ARE NOT SPHERICALLY SYMMETRIC, BUT ELONGATED AS INFRARED DARK CLOUDS OR LONG LINEAR FILAMENTS. THEIR STAR-FORMING CHARACTERISTICS ARE THOUGHT TO BE SENSITIVE TO THE GEOMETRIES. WE PROPOSE A SYSTEMATIC, DETAILED STUDY OF A SAMPLE OF 168 OF THESE DARK CLOUDS SPANNING A WIDE RANGE OF PARAMETERS USING NEW ARCHIVAL DATA FROM HERSCHEL AND SPITZER. ARCHIVAL HERSCHEL PHOTOMETRY IN PARTICULAR ENABLES FOR THE FIRST TIME A SENSITIVE, SYSTEMATIC STUDY OF THE FULL FAR-INFRARED CONTINUUM OF THESE OBJECTS. WE HAVE DISTANCE DETERMINATIONS AND ANCILLARY MOLECULE LINE MEASUREMENTS FOR ALL OF OUR SOURCES. TEN-BAND PHOTOMETRY (FROM 3.5UM TO 500UM) WILL LET US DETERMINE THE LUMINOSITIES, SPECTRAL ENERGY DISTRIBUTIONS (SEDS), AND ESTIMATE MASSES OF THESE COLD STRUCTURES AS FUNCTIONS OF THEIR STAR-FORMATION ACTIVITY. WE WILL PRODUCE DUST TEMPERATURE AND OPTICAL DEPTH MAPS THAT WILL ENABLE STATISTICAL STUDIES OF FILAMENTS AND THEIR CORES; WE EXPECT STATISTICS ON OVER 500 PROTOSTELLAR CORES. OUR SELECTED SOURCES SPAN A RANGE OF PHYSICAL CONDITIONS: DISTANCES FROM 1 TO 8 KPC, LENGTHS FROM 0.1 TO 80 PC, ASPECT RATIOS FROM BELOW 2 TO ABOVE 8, NOMINAL CORE MASSES FROM ABOUT 1 TO 500 MO, AND A RANGE OF GEOMETRIES INCLUDING LINEAR, BRANCHING, HUB-FILAMENT, AND NETWORK CONFIGURATIONS. WE PLAN TO USE THE EXTENDED ROBITAILLE YSO MODELS AND SUNRISE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODELS FOR PRESTELLAR CORES TO ANALYZE A GENERIC SET OF THE MOST COMMON OBJECTS, AND THEN TEST THEIR APPLICABILITY ACROSS THE SAMPLE. WE WILL ALSO BRING OTHER DATA TO BEAR (WISE; 2MASS, MILLIMETER) AS IS USEFUL. WE ADDRESS THREE CURRENT, MULTI-FACETED PROBLEMS: (1) WHAT ARE THE DENSITY, TEMPERATURE AND OPTICAL DEPTH STRUCTURES OF FILAMENTS AND THEIR CORES? HOW DO THESE PARAMETERS VARY SPATIALLY FOR CORES AND THE INTER-CORE REGIONS? HOW DO THESE PARAMETERS CORRELATE TO FILAMENTARY OR ENVIRONMENTAL PROPERTIES? (2) WHAT IS THE STATISTICAL DISTRIBUTION OF THESE PROPERTIES; IN PARTICULAR, WHAT IS THE POPULATION DISTRIBUTION OF CORE MASSES, AND THE TRENDS OF TEMPERATURE, LUMINOSITY, AND CLUSTERING? (3) HOW WELL DO THE MODELS WORK? DOES THE DEGREE OF STAR FORMATION IN THESE ELONGATED STRUCTURES HELP DISCRIMINATE BETWEEN COMPETING MODELS OF ISOTHERMAL, TURBULENT (OR 2-COMPONENT TURBULENT) COLLAPSE, OR COMPETITIVE ACCRETION? IS THERE EVIDENCE IN FILAMENTARY STRUCTURES FOR MAGNETIC EFFECTS (E.G., IN THE DENSITY VERSUS RADIUS), OR FOR OTHER MECHANISMS? WHAT LIGHT DO THESE MEASUREMENTS SHED ON HOW FILAMENTS AND THEIR CORES DEVELOPED? HOW CAN THE MODELS BE IMPROVED TO BETTER DESCRIBE THESE NEW OBSERVATIONS? THE TEAM INCLUDES EXPERTS ON THE OBSERVATIONS AND MODELING OF THE EARLY STAGES OF STAR FORMATION IN GENERAL, IRDCS, AND FILAMENTS, AND MULTI-WAVELENGTH ANALYSES. IT ALSO INCLUDES EXPERTISE IN INFRARED IMAGE PROCESSING, INCLUDING PRELIMINARY IN-HOUSE CODES FOR HERSCHEL ARCHIVAL PACS AND SPIRE DATA.

doc.ProductorServiceCode: AN12: R&D- MEDICAL: BIOMEDICAL (APPLIED RESEARCH/EXPLORATORY DEVELOPMENT)

doc.ContractDescription: ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT PROPERTIES OF MESOSCALE EDDIES IS THEIR ABILITY TO TRANSPORT SUCH DYNAMICALLY AND CLIMATICALLY IMPORTANT OCEANIC TRACERS, AS HEAT, SALT AND CARBON. RECENT STUDIES SUGGEST THAT THIS EDDY INDUCED TRANSPORT HAS COMPLEX NON-UNIFORM SPATIAL STRUCTURE AND IS OFTEN HIGHLY ANISOTROPIC. THE EDDY-INDUCED TRACER TRANSPORT IS PARAMETERIZED BY EDDY DIFFUSIVITY IN NON-EDDYRESOLVING CLIMATE MODELS, BUT THESE PARAMETERIZATIONS ARE OFTEN PURELY EMPIRICAL AND DO NOT ACCOUNT FOR THE OBSERVED COMPLEXITY OF THE EDDY FIELD. ON THE OTHER HAND, EMERGING HIGH RESOLUTION MODELS PARTLY RESOLVE THE MESOSCALE, BUT THE ACCURACY OF THEIR SIMULATION OF THE MOST IMPORTANT EDDY TRANSPORT PROPERTIES REQUIRES VERIFICATION. RELIABLE ESTIMATES OF THE EDDY INDUCED TRANSPORT ARE URGENTLY NEEDED FOR ADVANCING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF OCEAN AND CLIMATE DYNAMICS. SATELLITE ALTIMETRY BOTH THE CURRENT AND FUTURE SWOT MISSIONS PROVIDES THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WITH THE NEARLY GLOBAL NEARSURFACE GEOSTROPHIC VELOCITY ESTIMATES. USING SYNTHETIC LAGRANGIAN PARTICLE TRAJECTORIES, SIMULATED USING THESE ALTIMETRIC VELOCITIES, ONE CAN READILY DERIVE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES. HOWEVER, THE RELIABILITY AND INTERPRETATION OF THE RESULTING EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES PRESENTS A CHALLENGE BECAUSE OF THE LIMITED SPATIO TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, THE NON UNIFORM SPATIAL COVERAGE, AND THE ABSENCE OF NON-GEOSTROPHIC VELOCITY COMPONENTS IN ALTIMETRY DERIVED CURRENTS. WE PROPOSE TO UNDERTAKE A MULTI YEAR STUDY OF THE GLOBAL EDDY INDUCED MATERIAL TRANSPORT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PRODUCING THE MOST RELIABLE ALTIMETRY BASED DIFFUSIVITY ESTIMATES ALONG WITH THE CORRESPONDING MAPS OF THE LOCATION DEPENDENT UNCERTAINTY IN THESE ESTIMATES AND SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE OPTIMAL USE OF RAW ALONG-TRACK DATA FOR THESE ESTIMATES. WE WILL EXTEND OUR PREVIOUS STUDY IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC TO THE GLOBAL DOMAIN AND COMBINE IT WITH A SUITE OF CAREFULLY DESIGNED OBSERVING SYSTEM SIMULATION EXPERIMENTS OSSES. OUR OBJECTIVES ARE TO, 1, EXAMINE THE SENSITIVITY AND ACCURACY OF THE ALTIMETRY BASED EDDY DIFFUSIVITY ESTIMATES TO THE SPATIO TEMPORAL RESOLUTION OF THE UNDERLYING SSH FIELDS, 2, COME UP WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE OPTIMAL PROCESSING APPROACH FOR THE ALONGTRACK SSH MEASUREMENTS THAT YIELDS THE MOST RELIABLE ESTIMATES OF THE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES, AND 3, SYSTEMATICALLY DESCRIBE THE GLOBAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES ALONG WITH THEIR UNCERTAINTY LEVELS, SPATIAL INHOMOGENEITIES, ANISOTROPIC PROPERTIES, DEPENDENCE ON LARGE-SCALE PARAMETERS, AND IMPORTANCE OF MOTIONS NOT RESOLVED BY ALTIMETRY. THIS STUDY DIRECTLY ADDRESSES ONE OF THE RESEARCH THEMES IN THE PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHY PROGRAM BY CONTRIBUTING TO THE INTERPRETATION OF THE OCEAN MESOSCALE CIRCULATION USING SATELLITE DATA. THE RESULTS ARE EXPECTED TO ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SIGNIFICANCE OF EDDY TRANSPORT OF SUCH CLIMATICALLY IMPORTANT QUANTITIES AS HEAT AND CARBON AND ARE, THEREFORE, HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE U.S. CLIVAR OBJECTIVE TO, TO DESCRIBE AND UNDERSTAND THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES RESPONSIBLE FOR CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND PREDICTABILITY, THROUGH THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF OBSERVATIONS. THE RESULTS WILL ALSO HAVE IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR VALIDATION AND FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF CLIMATE MODELS THAT EITHER PARAMETERIZE OR PARTIALLY RESOLVE MESOSCALE EDDIES, IN DIRECT RELEVANCE TO ANOTHER CLIVAR OBJECTIVE TO, TO EXTEND THE RANGE AND ACCURACY OF SEASONAL TO INTERANNUAL CLIMATE PREDICTION THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF GLOBAL COUPLED PREDICTIVE MODELS.

doc.ContractDescription: DESPITE ITS LOW CONCENTRATION, STRATOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR HAS LARGE IMPACTS ON THE EARTH'S ENERGY BUDGET AND CLIMATE. RECENT STUDIES SUGGEST THAT EVEN SMALL CHANGES IN STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY MAY HAVE CLIMATE IMPACTS THAT ARE SIGNIFICANT COMPARED TO THOSE OF DECADAL INCREASES IN GREENHOUSE GASES. FUTURE CHANGES IN STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY AND OZONE CONCENTRATION IN RESPONSE TO CHANGING CLIMATE ARE SIGNIFICANT CLIMATE FEEDBACKS. WHILE THE TROPOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR CLIMATE FEEDBACK IS WELL REPRESENTED IN GLOBAL MODELS, PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHANGES IN STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY ARE HIGHLY UNCERTAIN BECAUSE OF GAPS IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PHYSICAL PROCESSES OCCURRING IN THE TROPICAL TROPOPAUSE LAYER (TTL, -13-18 KM), THE REGION OF THE ATMOSPHERE THAT CONTROLS THE COMPOSITION OF THE STRATOSPHERE. UNCERTAINTIES IN THE TTL CHEMICAL COMPOSITION ALSO LIMIT OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT FUTURE CHANGES IN STRATOSPHERIC OZONE. WE PROPOSE A SERIES OF MEASUREMENT CAMPAIGNS USING THE LONG-RANGE NASA GLOBAL HAWK. (GH) UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEM (UAS) TO DIRECTLY ADDRESS THESE PROBLEMS. A NUMBER OF TIL PROCESSES AFFECT STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY AND OZONE: DEEP CONVECTIVE TRANSPORT OF WATER VAPOR AND OTHER CHEMICAL CONSTITUENTS INTO THE TTL; THE FORMATION OF UBIQUITOUS THIN CIRRUS IN THE TTL (WHICH THEMSELVES HAVE A LARGE EFFECT ON THE RADIATION BUDGET AND CLIMATE); LIMITATION OF STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY BY SEDIMENTING ICE CRYSTALS IN TTL THIN CIRRUS; SLOW VERTICAL TRANSPORT THROUGH THE TTL; THE EFFECTS OF TROPICAL ATMOSPHERIC WAVES ON TTL THERMAL STRUCTURE, DEHYDRATION, AND TRANSPORT; AND THE CHEMISTRY OF SHORT-LIVED TRACE GASES. OBSERVATIONS OF TTL COMPOSITION ARE SPARSE COMPARED TO THOSE IN OTHER CLIMATICALLY IMPORTANT REGIONS, PARTLY BECAUSE THE HIGH TTL ALTITUDE LIMITS AIRCRAFT SAMPLING. FURTHER, THE UTILITY OF SATELLITE MEASUREMENTS OF TTL COMPOSITION IS REDUCED BY THE CHARACTERISTICALLY STRONG VERTICAL GRADIENTS IN THE TTL. AS A RESULT, TTL PROCESSES ARE NOT WELL REPRESENTED IN GLOBAL MODELS. THIS INVESTIGATION WILL PROVIDE DATA NEEDED TO ADDRESS THESE SHORTCOMINGS: HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTION (ONLY OBTAINABLE BY AIRCRAFT) MEASUREMENTS OVER LARGE GEOGRAPHICAL REGIONS (REQUIRING THE GR RANGE) AND OVER MULTIPLE SEASONS. THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION FILLS SEVERAL SIGNIFICANT GAPS IN ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCE IDENTIFIED IN THE NASA DECADAL SURVEY INVOLVING CLIMATE CHANGE, STRATOSPHERIC OZONE, AND STRATOSPHERE-TROPOSPHERE EXCHANGE. SCIENCE QUESTIONS THAT WILL BE ADDRESSED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: 1. WHAT PROCESSES CONTROL THE TROPICAL TROPOPAUSE TEMPERATURE AND THE HUMIDITY OF AIR ENTERING THE STRATOSPHERE (INCLUDING THEIR SEASONAL CYCLES)? 2. WHAT ARE THE DOMINANT PATHWAYS FOR VERTICAL TRANSPORT FROM CONVECTIVE DETRAINMENT ALTITUDES IN THE TTL UP TO THE TROPICAL TROPOPAUSE IN DIFFERENT SEASONS? 3. WHAT ARE THE FORMATION PROCESSES, MICROPHYSICAL PROPERTIES, AND CLIMATE IMPACT OF TTL CIRRUS, AND HOW DO THESE CLOUDS REGULATE THE HUMIDITY OF AIR ENTERING THE STRATOSPHERE? 4. WHAT ARE THE CHEMICAL AND TRANSPORT PROCESSES THAT DRIVE THE BUDGETS OF PRECURSORS OF OZONE-DESTROYING SUBSTANCES SUCH AS SHORT-LIVED HALOGEN COMPOUNDS? 5. HOW WILL TTL CIRRUS, STRATOSPHERIC HUMIDITY, AND STRATOSPHERIC OZONE RESPOND TO A CHANGING CLIMATE, AND WHAT ARE THE RESULTING FEEDBACK EFFECTS?

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF THE EVOLUTION OF THE NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM VIA THE NEXT GENERATION AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM PROGRAM DEPENDS ON ENABLING NEW OPERATIONAL CONCEPTS TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY. DECREASING THE SPACING BETWEEN AIRCRAFT ON TAKEOFF AND LANDING WOULD INCREASE THE THROUGHPUT OF AIRPORTS. ON-BOARD SENSING CAPABILITY FOR WAKE VORTICES COULD ALLOW AIRCRAFT TO OPERATE WITH REDUCED SPACINGS. WAKE VORTICES CAN BE DETECTED BY A LIDAR LOCATED ON THE AIRCRAFT, BUT SUCH A SYSTEM NEEDS TO BE SMALL, LIGHTWEIGHT, RUGGED, AND REQUIRE MINIMAL MAINTENANCE. THE PHASE I PROGRAM SHOWED THE FEASIBILITY OF AN INTRINSICALLY LOWCOST, COHERENT LIDAR THAT WOULD BE SUITABLE FOR DEPLOYMENT ON COMMERCIAL AIRLINERS FOR AXIAL WAKE VORTEX DETECTION. THE LOW-COST LIDAR TEST BED WAS USED TO DEMONSTRATE MEASUREMENT OF AEROSOL RETURNS. THE PROGRAM ALSO ASSESSED THE FEASIBILITY OF USING THE LIDAR FOR REMOTE DETECTION OF CLEAR AIR TURBULENCE AND VOLCANIC ASH CLOUDS. THE PROGRAM DEVELOPED A CONCEPTUAL DESIGN FOR A PROTOTYPE SYSTEM THAT WOULD BE FABRICATED AND GROUND TESTED IN THE PHASE II PROGRAM. THE PHASE II PROGRAM WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE AN ENGINEERING PROTOTYPE COMPACT COHERENT DOPPLER LIDAR AND DEMONSTRATE IT BY MEASURING AMBIENT WIND FIELDS AT NEARBY VENUES.
doc.MajorAgency: LOW-COST LIDAR FOR WAKE-VORTEX AND OTHER HAZARD DE
